newsitem.title: MEXICO: Vigilante fever spreads in southern Mexico.
newsitem.headline: Vigilante fever spreads in southern Mexico.

text.p: Poor farmers in a downtrodden patch of southeastern Mexico on Friday threatened to join a mob of vigilantes who rounded up 17 alleged criminals this week and burned their homes.

In a revenge spree this week for a spate of crop thefts, hundreds of villagers in the community of Independencia held the 17 men for 20 hours before they were rescued by state police and turned over to Tabasco state authorities.
The assualt began on Wednesday when five homes belonging to the suspects were set ablaze.

In five neighbouring villages in an area known as C-17 Plan Chontalpa, locals enraged over the increase in petty crime threatened to set up their own armed vigilante mobs to join those in Independencia.
"We know who they are and we're going to get together to begin to catch them ourselves," Ovidio de la Cruz Surita, representative of some 7,000 families in the area, told Reuters.

Authorities in Villahermosa, the state capital of Tabasco some 30 miles (48 km) northwest of Cardenas, confirmed that vigilante attacks were on the rise, and said they were deciding whether to prosecute the ringleaders.
The original incident, in Independencia, almost boiled over into lynchings when villagers caught the 17 they suspected of assaults, robberies and the stealing of crops.
"We want justice. We don't want them here," Jose Garica Garcia, elected leader of Indepedencia, told Reuters on Thursday. Garcia, however, was not a member of the mob.

Tabasco is a tropical state near the Yucatan peninsula, where corn and sugar cane are key crops. But land is scarce and polluted as a result of intense oil drilling in the region by state oil monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex).
Attempted lynchings have become the latest form of score-settling. Earlier this year three alleged thieves were taken from their homes, beaten, doused with gasoline and nearly set alight.
Villagers on Thursday said the band's recent attack on a married couple was the last straw in an alleged crime spree.
After rounding up the 17 men, the mob took them to the centre of town, where a list of allegations was read publicly and the men declared guilty. It was then that police intervened, witnesses said.
